title: Department of Defense support for 2008 documentary "Full Battle Rattle"

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Department of Defense support for 2008 documentary "Full Battle Rattle"
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Any documents pertaining to collaboration between the Department of Defense (DoD) and the production of the 2008 documentary movie "Full Battle Rattle," directed by Jesse Moss and Tony Gerber. The documentary was filmed in a US Army installation in the Mojave Desert, used for conducting war simulations of the Iraq theater. I request any and all documents pertaining to DoD involvement with the production of "Full Battle Rattle." Such documents may include but should not be limited to: script notes; production assistance agreements; and all records of communications between employees of DoD and members of the cast, crew, and production company of "Full Battle Rattle," including memos, notes of meetings and conference calls, emails, and other forms of communication.

I am the Director of Research Operations at a 501(c)(3) non-profit organization called The Decoding Culture Foundation. These documents will be used for public education and research purposes. I therefore request a waiver of all fees that may otherwise apply. Attached is a document with organization letterhead confirming my position, as well as the organization's 501(c)(3) application and approval form.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Brett Carollo

communications.subject: Virginia Freedom of Information Act Request: Uniforms/UMS Activity Fees
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Virginia Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Records  showing what specifically is included in the “Uniforms / UMA Activities  fee” as well as the financial records showing ledger level itemized income and expenditures for Uniforms / UMA Activities  fees for the 2020 – 2021, 2021 – 2022, 2022 – 2023, 2023 – 2024 and 2024 – 2025 academic years including how this fee per cadet was determine, who approved the fee, all income to this fund by source, and all expenditures for these funds to the line-item level. For 2024 – 2025 include what is programmed, allocated and committed to date. These should include the portion of these fees allocated for uniforms and UMA Activities to include, without limitation, a definition of each “UMA Activity”. Itemized expenditures for uniforms and UMA Activities should total the amount reported as collected from Cadets and other identified sources. Itemized expenditures are requested for the amount allocated and line-item expenditures to each areas and what was budgeted for each for the selected academic years what will enable analysis of allocated to expended and within expenditures identify what products or services were procured. This information should be readily available in any reasonable standard accounting system using acceptable accounting practices and so should not require a significant level of efforts to identify and provide those records.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Tom Nash, a citizen of Virginia, in coordination with Anonymous.

communications.subject: Virginia Freedom of Information Act Request: Cadet Activity Fees
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Virginia Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Records  showing what specifically is included in the “Cadet Facilities/Activity” as well as the financial records showing ledger itemized income and expenditures for Cadet Facilities/Activity fees for the 2008 – 2009, 2009 – 2010, 2020 – 2021, 2021 – 2022, 2022 – 2023, 2023 – 2024 and 2024 – 2025 academic years including how this fee per cadet was determine, who approved the fee, all income to this fund by source, and all expenditures for these funds to the line-item level by student or other activity. For 2024 – 2025 include what is programmed, allocated and committed to date. Itemized expenditures are requested for the amount allocated and line-item expenditures to each club and student organization and what was budgeted for each for the selected academic years what will enable analysis of allocated to expended and within expenditures identify what products or services were procured. These should include the portion of these fees allocated for cadet facilities/activities consisting of facilities maintenance, debt service, cadet counseling services, cadet organizations and any other expenditures from this fund by office or organization that expended the funds, by supply or service purchased. For example, “Cadet Program Board” is described as “provides entertainment, relaxation and fun” so records should contain what specific entertainment, relaxation and fun” activities and other costs were paid out of the accounts. Itemized expenditures by category and organization should total the amount reported as collected from Cadets and other identified sources. This information should be readily available in any reasonable standard accounting system using acceptable accounting practices and so should not require a significant level of efforts to identify and provide those records.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Tom Nash, a citizen of Virginia, in coordination with Anonymous.

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Sanchez-Castro ICE Death Docs
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Records pertaining to the death in custody of Jose Manuel Sanchez Castro on October 27, 2024. See https://www.ice.gov/doclib/foia/reports/ddrJoseManuelSanchezCastro.pdf. 

Specifically, I request: 
1. The IHSC Mortality Review.
2. The ICE OPR ERAU Detainee Death Review Report.
3. The Healthcare and Security Compliance Analysis SME report. 
4. The Root Cause Analysis, if any.
5. The Corrective Action Plan created based on findings in records 1-4 above, if any. 
6. The Contract Discrepancy Report issued based on any findings in records 1-4 above, if any. 
7. Any cover letter, transmittal letter, or memorandum that accompanied records 1-6 above as these records were transmitted to ICE leadership. 

Requestor Information
I make this request as a member of the media engaged primarily in information dissemination and seek a fee waiver based on this designation. I am an independent journalist engaged in both self-published documentation of deaths in DHS custody (e.g., via the DetentionKills substack) and also in edited works appearing or under contract with outlets such as Prism, the Atlanta Community Press Collective. I was also a contributing author to the recent civil society report on deaths in ICE custody, available here: https://assets.aclu.org/live/uploads/2024/06/2024-07-01-ICE-Detainee-Deaths.pdf. 

Expedited Processing Request 
Pursuant to 6 C.F.R. 5.5(e), I request expedited processing and make the following statements under penalty of perjury pursuant to 28 USC 1746: 

1. Deaths in ICE custody increased 300% in FY24 after reaching a 40-year low in each of the two previous fiscal years.  
2. The GEO Group operates the Northwest ICE Processing Center, where Mr. Sanchez Castro was detained prior to his death. 
3. The GEO Group has previously been found by ICE to have failed to comply with contractually mandated standards in ways that contributed to the deaths of immigrants in ICE custody. 
4. ICE has previously assessed contractual penalties against GEO based on those findings. 
5. ICE falsely claims in the wake of deaths in custody that people received 24/7 emergency medical treatment; the agency's own Mortality Reviews frequently find such care was not provided, or was deficient and outside safe limits of practice. 
6. There is an urgent need to inform the public about the track record of ICE detention contractors as the agency considers awarding billions of dollars in new contracts to detain human beings. 
7. Deaths in ICE custody have been the subject of widespread media attention raising serious questions of government wrongdoing. 
8. ICE ceased releasing Detainee Death Review Reports affirmatively following the death of Roger Rayson in GEO's care in 2017, forcing the public to obtain these records via FOIA. 
9. ICE is serially outside processing times required by FOIA, leading to multiple federal courts holding the agency has a pattern and practice of violating the law when it comes to untimely responses. 
10. Expedited processing of this request will allow the public to critically assess the performance of contractors who receive taxpayer funds, and to assess preventive measures that will avoid future in-custody deaths.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Andrew Free

communications.subject: New York Freedom of Information Law Request: Thorpe Disicpline Records
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the New York Freedom of Information Law, I hereby request the following records:

The complete disciplinary records of Superintendent Bennie Thorpe. As of January 2025, Thorpe was superintendent of Marcy Correctional Facility.

Citing the FOIL Subject Matter List of the Department of Corrections and Community Supervision last known to be updated February 16, 2021, the record would be listed under subheading "EMPLOYEE SUBJECTS" where this describes the following described records:

* Employee Investigations
* Executive Facility Files
* Human Resources/Personnel
* Labor Relations

Per legislation signed by the Governor on June 12, 2020, as Chapter 96 of the New York State Laws of 2020, these are now subject to release upon request through the state's Freedom of Information Law; records may not be withheld citing New York State Civil Rights Law 50-a (repealed).

Explicitly releasable are records including:

* complaints, allegations, and charges;
* the name of the employee complained of or charged;
* the transcript of any disciplinary trial or hearing, including any exhibits introduced at such trial or hearing;
* the disposition of any disciplinary proceeding;
* the final written opinion or memorandum supporting the disposition and discipline imposed including the agency's complete factual findings and its analysis of the conduct and appropriate discipline of the covered employee.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Chris Gelardi

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Penetrate
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Records mentioning, relating to or generated during the course of the investigation code named "Penetrate",  which detail the Bureau's investigation of a Cuban intelligence agent operating in Puerto Rico, covering the years 1962 through 1965. This investigation is known to have used mail covers. The following file numbers are associated with Penetrate: 65-HQ-67842, 65-SJ-398, 65-MM-2940. The HQ file number is also cited in previously released records on MIRA, which potentially identify Penetrate as Filiberto Inocencio Ojeda-Rios, the subject of a 1970 fugitive case (https://archive.org/details/MovimentoIndependentistaRevolucionarioEnArmas/SJ-100-12315_4_04_70/page/n75/mode/2up).

communications.subject: Illinois Freedom of Information Act. Request: Governance: 2024, Outside Legal Bills, Cozen
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Illinois Freedom of Information Act., I hereby request the following records:

Since January 1, 2024 through current:

1) Copies of all invoices from the Cozen O'Connor law firm;

2) Copies of records of payments by CPS/Chicago Board of Education to Cozen O'Connor law firm. I want the actual bills as well as proof of payment by the district.

3) Any and all letters of engagement between CPS/Chicago Board of Education and Cozen O'Connor law firm, including any modifications or changes.

This request is made on behalf of The FOIA Bakery. Because this request is in the public interest for Illinois nonprofit The FOIA Bakery’s work to advocate for public education, please waive any fees in accordance with 5 ILCS § 140/6(c). Feel free to contact me with any questions, or if clarification is needed.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Miriam Bhimani

Chicago Public Schools (CPS) responds to all public records requests in accordance with the Illinois Freedom of Information Act (FOIA), 5 ILCS 140/1 et seq. 
Due to the volume and complexity of requests received in the normal course of business, CPS is extending the time for its initial response to your request by an additional 5 business days (to 10 business days total beginning on the first business day following receipt of the request) pursuant to 5 ILCS 140/3(e)(v) which allows for the examination and evaluation of the requested records by personnel to determine if they are exempt from disclosure under Section 7 of Illinois FOIA or should be revealed only with appropriate deletions. 
Upon the completion of a response, CPS will provide the first 50 pages to you at no charge.  If a response is more than 50 pages, a fee of 15¢ per page will be charged for each additional page. All applicable fees must be paid prior to the copying. CPS will inform you of any fees due if your paper response exceeds 50 pages. You can monitor the progress of your request at the link below and you’ll receive an email when your request has been completed. Thank you for using the CPS FOIA Center.

communications.subject: Welcome to the FOIA Center!
communications.communication:
Thank you for registering with the CPS FOIA Center. Please log in to the FOIA Center to update any contact or password information and to track the progress of your request. 
 Your Login ID is:  178903-46497245@requests.muckrock.com If you did not submit your request through the Records Center but are receiving this e-mail, an account has been created for you where you can track and monitor the status of your request, and receive any documents in response to your request. communications.subject: Non-Commercial FOIA Request :: N016643-010225
Freedom of Information Act Request: Dumitrascu OMDC CAP Records
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Description of Records Sought: 
1. All records constituting a Corrective Action Plan created for the ICE Otay Mesa Detention Center (OMDC) in response to the findings and recommendations of the ICE Health Services Corps (IHSC) Mortality Review Committee's May 12, 2023, Mortality Review of the death of Cristian Dumitrascu on March 5, 2023, inside OMDC. OMDC is located within the San Diego ERO Area of Responsibility. A copy of the IHSC Mortality Review obtained via ICE FOIA 2024-ICFO-28664 is publicly available here: https://www.documentcloud.org/documents/25472204-dumitrascu-mortality-review-2024-icfo-28664-001/. 

2. A record, if any, reflecting ICE's determination not to impose a corrective action plan in response to the IHSC Mortality Review Committee's findings and recommendations. 

3. Any Contract Discrepancy Report and relating correspondence between ICE and CoreCivic reflecting a deduction or withholding of invoiced funds by ICE based on the findings of IHSC's Mortality Review Committee that Core Civic staff fell short of contractually required standards in Mr. Dumitrascu's care and the associated facility response.

Suggested Search Parameters, Time Period, Custodians, and Methodology
Please task a search that includes Mr. Dumitrascu's name and Alien registration, A246 302 355 as case numbers associated with the Mortality Review.
An adequate search should cover a date range commencing on or before May 12, 2023, and continuing through the date on which the agency tasks an adequate search responsive to this request. 
Custodians to task with this search include, but are not limited to, Stewart D. Smith, Ada I. Rivera, the IHSC Chief of Staff, and the IHSC Chief of the Investigations Unit, as well as ICE OAQ, the ICE ERO SDO Field Office Director, the ICE Chief of Staff, the Acting ICE Director, the Director of Custody Management, and the Deputy Assistant Director of Health Care Compliance. 
Please process the results of this search by first locating the following responsive records: (a) Corrective Action Plan; (2) Contract Discrepancy Report; (3) associated communications. These documents, once located, will provide additional, obvious leads that will yield responsive records as to the remainder of the request. 

Requestors
I make this request on behalf of the Mami Chelo Foundation, a 501(c)(3) nonprofit organization located in New York, New York. Mami Chelo holds power of attorney for Mr. Dumitrascu's Next-of-Kin, in addition to serving as a resource for incarcerated and formerly incarcerated migrants and refugees. I also seek these records on my own behalf as an independent, freelance journalist and a member of the media primarily engaged in the dissemination of information. 

Expedited Processing Request and Sworn Statement 
Mami Chelo respectfully requests expedited processing based on an urgent need to inform the public about actual or alleged government misconduct, and based on 6 C.F.R. 5.5(e), because preventable deaths in ICE custody constitute a matter of widespread media attention about which there exist questions as to the propriety and legality of the government's actions. In support of this expedited processing request, I make the following statements under penalty of perjury pursuant to 28 USC 1746 and affirm that they are true and correct to the best of my knowledge and understanding: 

1. I am a member of the media, primarily engaged in the dissemination of information.
2. There is an urgency to inform the public about the circumstances of Mr. Dumitrascu's death.
3. At least 7 people detained in the same area as Mr. Dumitrascu declared under oath that his care was delayed by CoreCivic staff.
4. Multiple individuals detained with Mr. Dumitrascu on the night of his death declared under oath that CoreCivic shut off telephone lines in the hours following his death -- preventing them from communicating what happened.
5. At least one person detained with Mr. Dumitrascu on the night of his death alleged CoreCivic and ICE accelerated the process of his removal in retaliation for attempting to share information about the death.
6. CoreCivic facilities have previously been fined for negligence and contract violations that preceded deaths in ICE custody. See, e.g., https://www.documentcloud.org/documents/24529304-stewart-contract-discrepancy-dec-2018.
7. At least 55 deaths have occurred at CoreCivic's ICE facilities since 2003--more than any other ICE contractor.
8. Since early 2017, ICE ceased affirmatively publishing detainee death reviews, forcing families to file FOIAs and sue when their loved ones die in order to obtain basic information on the government's findings.
9. Congress recently approved the expansion of ICE detention by more than 20% -- up 7,500 beds to 41,500 funded.
10. DHS and the present administration proposed cuts to inspection budgets for ICE detention centers, rendering the public less able to assess the lethality of ICE detention operations, including those at Otay Mesa.
11. The IHSC Mortality Review ICE completed on May 12, 2023, concluded Mr. Dumitrascu received deficient emergency medical care. 
12. ICE is currently poised to award additional contract to the care provider -- CoreCivic -- despite its documented history of being the most lethal detention contract in the ICE detention system. 
13. We will make these records immediately available to the public and intend to publish a report based on them. 

Thank you in advance for your consideration.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Andrew Free

communications.subject: City Public Records Request :: C376388-010225
communications.communication:
Dear david: 
 
The City of Portland acknowledges receipt of your Public Records Request.  Your request was received in this office on January 02, 2025 and given the reference number C376388-010225 for tracking purposes. 
 
Record Requested:  To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Oregon Public Records Law, I hereby request the following records:

To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Ohio Open Records Law, I hereby request the following records:

I am writing to formally request access to public records under the Freedom of Information Act (FOIA). Specifically, I am requesting any and all records and materials related to the case of

Suspect Name: Geoffrey Hammond
Description/Headline: Jury deadlocked over road rage murder case, defendant found guilty on assault charges
link: https://mynbc15.com/news/nation-world/jury-decision-imminent-in-portland-road-rage-incident-outside-of-moxy-hotel-geoffrey-hammond-ryan-martin-downtown-multnomah-county
State: Portland OR
Law Enforcement: Portland Oregon Police

included but not limited to the following:
Documents:
Incident reports
Investigation reports
Officer statements
Witness statements
Any other relevant case files

Footage:
Body camera footage from officers on the scene
Dash camera footage
Police surveillance camera footage
Private/public surveillance footage from nearby locations
Any footage collected as evidence or during the investigation

Audio:
911 calls
Police radio communications
Any other audio recordings related to the case
Visual Media:
Crime scene photographs
Surveillance stills
Photographs taken during the investigation

Court Records:
Transcripts from court hearings or proceedings
Any video/audio footage from court hearings
Court orders or any other court-related documents

Please include any and all materials, regardless of format (digital or physical), including those not listed above that are related to the case in question.
Additionally, if this request has been sent to the wrong department or agency, I would appreciate it if you could provide guidance or contact information for the correct department or agency that handles such requests.

If any part of the request is denied or redacted, please provide a detailed explanation of the specific legal exemption that applies.
Thank you for your attention to this matter. I look forward to your timely response within the period mandated by FOIA.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days.

Sincerely,

david yupa

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days.

Sincerely,

david yupa

Upload documents directly: https://accounts.muckrock.com/accounts/login/?next=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.muckrock.com%2Faccounts%2Flogin%2F%3Fnext%3D%252Faccounts%252Fagency_login%252Fcity-of-portland-oregon-16871%252Ffoia-request-for-case-related-materials-geoffrey-hammond-178878%252F%253F&url_auth_token=AABeIvtBww_r6UVn80mlnqqjyMc%3A1tTbPU%3AZRyfMlRwrnLDhRx4FcznM7iAVbFt-WeLjij0eTsqEzU 
At this time, the City is uncertain whether it is the custodian of the requested record.  The City will review your request to determine if it has responsive records.  The City will then gather an estimate of the costs to provide copies of requested public records for which the City does not claim an exemption from disclosure.  The City is permitted to charge its actual costs to provide records.  Fees include research time to locate and analyze the requested records,  even if no records are located or if the requested records are  determined to be exempt from disclosure. 
 
You can monitor the progress of your request at the link below.  Thank you for using the Portland Public Records Request Center.
